webTitle: Beautiful Games: stylised football posters

fields.standfirst: In a collaboration between Spiel football magazine and Liverpool John Moores University, students were set a live brief to produce work on the theme of the Ballon d'Or - European football's most prestigious individual prize. Mark Frances captured the brief neatly to produce these distinctive posters of the game's greatest stars. Each player is subtly represented using graphics reflective of their era and heritage; the poster for Michel Platini recalls the style of the Swiss designer and former art director at Jardin des Modes, Jean Widmer, for example, while the Johan Cruyff poster is a simple but effective homage to the grid-like ethos of the Dutch modernist typographer, Wim Crouwel. Rather appropriately, Crouwel once mused: "The grid is like the lines on a football field; you can play a great game in the grid or a lousy game, but the goal is to play a really fine game." Cruyff would surely agree.
fields.headline: Beautiful Games: stylised football posters
fields.trailText: In a collaboration between Spiel football magazine and Liverpool John Moores University, students were set a live brief to produce work on the theme of the Ballon d'Or. Mark Frances captured the brief neatly to produce these distinctive posters

webTitle: Guardian Camera Club: Geraltyna's portfolio

fields.standfirst:
A review of Geraltyna's portfolio.

Image '1' creates lines and shapes from the light itself, but the dark corners are more intriguing. '2' is more open, but it's still all about the light and shade. '3' introduces the natural environment and the sky, but the brutal angles still dominate. '4' tilts in a seasick fashion, all the interesting stuff seems to be at the lower right, where the trees lead us out of the frame. The best image is '5', with its grand sweep, the ditch, and a tiny road sign seemingly continuing the line forever. The clean elegance of '6' ends this interesting, and 'diagonal' dominated set
fields.headline: Guardian Camera Club: Geraltyna's portfolio
fields.trailText: A review of Geraltyna's portfolio

webTitle: Did Ed Miliband's social security speech get it right? | The panel

fields.standfirst: Our panel scrutinises the Labour leader's speech on issues from housing to long-term unemployment
fields.headline: Did Ed Miliband's social security speech get it right?
fields.trailText: The panel: John Harris, Melissa Kite, Ruth Lister, Sue Marsh, Frank Field, Graeme Cooke, Imran Hussain and Ian Mulheirn scrutinise the Labour leader's speech on issues from housing to long-term unemployment

tags.bio: Melissa Kite is contributing editor of The Spectator. She is the author of the book Real Life, published by Constable. She was deputy political editor of the Sunday Telegraph until 2011. Her alter ego is Tamzin Lightwater, who recounted life at Tory HQ in the anonymous Spectator satirical column, Diary of a Notting Hill Nobody

Sue Marsh is married with two small children. She campaigns to raise awareness of hidden disabilities and long term illness. A sufferer of severe Crohn's Disease for nearly three decades, Sue set up the blog Diary of a Benefit Scrounger to raise awareness of life with a chronic illness
John Harris is a journalist and author, who writes regularly for the Guardian about a range of subjects built around politics, popular culture and music
Ruth Lister is a Labour peer, emeritus professor of social policy at Loughborough University and chair of the Compass management committee

Frank Field has been the elected Member of Parliament for Birkenhead since 1979. He served as minister for Welfare Reform in the first Blair government. Before his election in 1979 he ran the Child Poverty Action Group, and was director of the UK's Low Pay Unit. He is author of many books on social policy including Neighbours from Hell (2003). His blog is at
www.frankfield.co.uk/blog
Graeme Cooke is research director of the IPPR

Ian Mulheirn was appointed director of the Social Market Foundation in October 2008. He joined the Social Market Foundation as the chief economist in February 2008, after three years as an economic adviser at HM Treasury. He has worked in a variety of policy areas including child poverty, savings and investment, welfare to work and higher education funding. He leads the SMF's work on public service reform, and was recently a specialist adviser to the work and pensions committee inquiry into the Work Programme

tags.bio:
Jason Burke is the south Asia correspondent of The Guardian and The Observer newspapers.

In more than a decade as a staff correspondent with the papers Burke has reported on a wide range of subjects in countries from Algeria to Cambodia, from Uzebkistan to Zimbabwe. 

Based in Pakistan from 1998 to 2002,  reporting from Afghanistan under the Taliban and during the war of 2001, he has returned to both Pakistan and Afghanistan many times since. Burke has also worked extensively in the Middle East, reporting from Iraq before, during and after the war of 2003. He has specialised in conflict, terrorism and Islamic militancy.

Currently based in New Delhi, he covers a wide range of social, political and cultural topics across South Asia. He is a regular commentator on television and radio.

Burke is the author of Al-Qaeda: the true story of radical Islam, published in 2003, which analysed the role of the militant group and its ideology and described the complex reality of modern Islamic radicalism. A second book, On The Road To Kandahar, was published in 2006. Burke speaks good French, average Hindi and Urdu and terrible Arabic.

tags.bio: Denis Campbell is health correspondent with the Guardian and the Observer. Since joining the Observer in 1999 he has covered sports news, social affairs and education. He previously worked for the Herald, Scotland on Sunday, Time Out and the Irish Times

fields.headline: NRL: five things to look out for
fields.trailText: Matt Cleary: Almost everyone's hurting after Origin, including plenty who didn't play in it. Now Kiwis may be added to the house of pain

tags.bio: Matt Cleary is a freelance sports journalist from Sydney who contributes to Inside Sport, Inside Cricket, Inside Rugby and several golf and travel magazines who pay him to play golf on holidays. The Australian Golf Writers Association once gave him an award for playing golf in Ireland. Australian Golf Digest paid him to spend four months playing golf on a full lap of Australia. Each week Rugby League Week pays him to drink beer and watch rugby league. Chances are he has a better job than you

James Ball is a data journalist working for the Guardian investigations team. He joined the Guardian from Wikileaks, and the Bureau of Investigative Journalism. He is the Washington Post Laurence Stern Fellow for 2012.
